bibl.title: Notes by Jefferson Randolph Kean for the Journal of Association of Military Surgeons, September 28, 1926

div1.p: Kean provides his analysis of the date of the initiation of anti-mosquito efforts in Havana. He cites a report by William Crawford Gorgas, which was written in 1904.

div1.head: Notes by Jefferson Randolph Kean for the Journal of Association of Military Surgeons, September 28, 1926
div1.p:
Journal of Assn of Military Surgeons
(Printer: This to go at bottom of page)

*Note by Editor: The date of the beginning of the
warfare against Yellow Fever in Havana is epochal, and there-
fore of interest and importance. The date, Feb. 4, 1901,
given by General Winter, is from the final Report of Gorgas
as Chief Sanitary Officer of Havana (dated Washington, July
12, 1902) and it seems certain that it was a clerical error.
The reasons for thinking so are that he was not at that time
a convert to the mosquito theory, as formulated by Reed, and
in other articles he gives a later date. In the same report,
he states (page 3):

“In February, 1901, Dr. Reed read a paper before
the International Sanitary Congress in Habana giving
the results of their work. The idea was so new and
so entirely contrary to all former theories on the
subject, and apparently to all former experience that
the paper was received with scanty belief. I myself
had seen the work and was convinced that the mosquito
could convey yellow fever but I was hardly prepared
to believe that it was the only way or even the ordin-
ary way of conveying the disease.”

In a pamphlet prepared at the request of Surgeon
General O'Reilly for distribution to Medical and Sanitary
Officers (A Few General Directions with Regard to Destroying
Mosquitoes, particularly the Yellow Fever Mosquito. By W. C.
Gorgas, Col. M.C., U.S. Army, Gov. Printing Office, 1904),
Colonel Gorgas states (page 10 speaking of house inspections
for breeding places):

“At the first report on this subject, I think it
was in March, 1901, we found that we had in Havana in
the neighborhood of 26,000 different water deposite
which contained wigglers, most of them of the yellow
fever variety. ****** The report of January, 1902, after
about ten months of this mosquito work showed that
within the city limits less than 300 premises had
wigglers upon them”. (Italics in above quotations
are the Editor's)

Reed gives the date of beginning work as February
15, and this doubtless refers to the formulation of plans at
Sanitary Headquarters rather than the activities of mosquito
squads in the patios of Havana. It is a safe bet that any
physical attack on the mosquito in the City of Havana before
the first of March, 1901 was limited to the ancient and auto-
matic manual response to the stimulus of a bite.
